Additional findings showed that Welsh speakers who contributed to the inquiry often felt awkward and had difficulty expressing their feelings to English-speaking doctors. The bill seeks to annul sections of the UK's 2016 Trade Union Act, altering current limitations on industrial actions within the NHS, the fire service, schools, and other devolved Welsh services. UK ministers contend that industrial relations fall under Westminster's jurisdiction. A significant aspect of the UK law requires strikes to have the support of 40% of a union's members in a ballot. However, the Welsh Assembly's Equality, Local Government, and Communities Committee members agreed that new legislation is essential to sustain Wales' "social-partnership" model. In March, Welsh Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford declared it would be a "democratic outrage" if London ministers blocked the Welsh Trade Union Bill. The Labour Welsh Government maintains that UK ministers should not enforce union activity restrictions in Wales on devolved services like the NHS and schools. The committee report was not unanimously supported, as Conservative AM Janet Finch-Saunders dissented.

Evha Jannath, 11, fell from a circular boat on the Splash Canyon ride at Drayton Manor during a school trip on Tuesday. In response, Alton Towers and Legoland Windsor have shut down similar water-based thrill rides. Drayton Manor announced it would stay closed on Friday for health and safety investigations. Merlin Entertainments, which operates Legoland and Alton Towers, confirmed it had closed similar rides "with immediate effect" as a precaution after learning of the fatal incident at Drayton Manor. They plan to reopen these rides on Friday. However, some places like Lightwater Valley in North Yorkshire and West Midland Safari Park have not closed rides following the incident at Drayton Manor.

Next up for Mark Warburton's team is Celtic in next Sunday's Scottish Cup semi-final. Rangers had struggled in the Challenge Cup under different formats, previously losing to Queen of the South, Raith Rovers, and Alloa Athletic. Members of the Royal College of Midwives (RCM) plan to halt work for four hours. They overwhelmingly voted 9-1 in favor of strike action, marking the first such decision in the college's 134-year history. The Department of Health expressed disappointment and stated it would collaborate with trusts to ensure safe service for mothers and babies. The department also mentioned its willingness to engage in discussions. The RCM is urgently seeking talks with the health minister to resolve the conflict. RCM NI director Bredagh Hughes emphasized that midwives are demanding the 1% pay raise granted to their counterparts in Wales, Scotland, and England. "It's crucial for women to understand that this dispute isn't against them but against the Department of Health and the employers," she said. "No woman will be put at risk; full emergency cover will be provided, and if necessary, midwives on the picket line will be called in to ensure adequate staffing."

Since Sunday, current account customers had been unable to make online payments with their debit cards, a measure the bank implemented "to prevent criminal activity." Construction workers must possess a CSCS card to demonstrate their skills and knowledge of health and safety. However, an investigation by BBC London and Newsnight uncovered systematic cheating. Carl Rhymer from the Construction Industry Training Board (CITB), one of the test providers, revealed that 6,000 cardholders would need to retake the exam. The CSCS (Construction Skills Certification Scheme) cards are considered the leading certification for builders in the UK and are required by nine of the country's largest construction firms, including Crossrail and Heathrow. The investigation revealed that many test centers were offering guaranteed passes for money, allowing non-English-speaking workers to gain qualifications and access dangerous construction sites. The BBC exposed Wep HSE in Ealing, where its award-winning director, Garet Estensen, was caught reading exam answers from a large screen and instructing candidates: "Follow me on screen, guys. I'm going to shout the correct answer." When confronted, Mr. Estensen did not respond. The investigation also uncovered two other centers engaging in similar fraudulent activities.

The stretch of land from Bo'ness Harbour to the former Kinneil colliery will be transformed into a wildlife and plant sanctuary, becoming the second Local Nature Reserve in the Falkirk Council area. The local authority aims to leverage this new status to secure funding for the region. This marks a significant shift for the site, which had been dedicated to heavy industry until the central colliery's closure in 1983, ending nearly 200 years of industrial use. Certain parts of the area have already been acknowledged for their environmental significance, with the mudflats and an "island" off the foreshore designated as a Special Protection Area. Councillor Adrian Mahoney, the convener of leisure, tourism, and community, expressed his approval of the new status for the Kinneil foreshore, noting that this year marks the 30th anniversary of the Kinneil Colliery’s closure, the last pit in the area.

Spencer Flower argued that his connection to a social housing company was irrelevant to a 2013 debate about housing in east Dorset. However, he was convicted of voting illegally since the company could have benefited from the approved plan. Despite this, the 72-year-old Conservative councillor will retain his public office position. Flower, from Verwood, Dorset, received a six-month conditional discharge and was ordered to pay £930 in costs. A district judge at Bournemouth Magistrates' Court concluded he violated laws under the Localism Act 2011. Outside the court, Flower did not comment on his political future, expressing surprise and disappointment at the court's decision, which he termed a technicality. He noted that the conditional discharge for six months was the least severe penalty and emphasized the absence of personal gain or intent.

Envoy Sigrid Kaag made her remarks as Syria seemed to miss a Sunday deadline to remove its chemical arsenal from the country. All of Syria's chemical weapons are set to be destroyed by 30 June. The agreement between Russia and the United States to eliminate Syria's chemical arsenal was established last year following a deadly sarin rocket attack near Damascus that killed hundreds. The multinational effort to dispose of these weapons is managed by the UN Security Council and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW). Although the UN's deadline for the complete destruction of Syria's chemical weapons is 30 June, Damascus had pledged to finish removing its stockpile by 27 April, after already missing several deadlines. "The bulk of the chemical weapons materials has been removed but not yet destroyed, and this is crucial for the 30 June deadline. Therefore, it is vital to retrieve the remaining chemical weapons materials still at one site," stated Ms. Kaag, head of the OPCW-UN mission.
